text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with spring vegetable Tartine
that's right as you may know Tartine is
just a fancy foodie word for an
open-faced sandwich and personally I do
think it sounds a little cooler but
that's not why I use it I use it because
Tartine takes up so many fewer
characters than help a face sandwich on
Twitter which is kind of a big deal when
I go on there to promote this later but
anyway let's go ahead and get started
with something I've cleverly hid
underneath that shaved vegetable salad
the real star of the show white
anchovies whoops hold on do not click
off the video yet just because I said
anchovy this is not the kind of anchovy
you don't like this is the other kind of
anchovy you don't know about and will
actually love because this type of
anchovy is not cured in salt but rather
marinated in vinegar and oil so they are
much less salty much milder in flavor
and yet still incredibly savory and
delicious so if you do want your spring
vegetable Tartine to taste like mine you
will need to find some of these and then
besides hopefully finding some Boca
Rene's we're also going to need to make
up a Meyer lemon aioli with which to
spread on our toast and that's going to
start by adding a few sliced garlic
cloves to our mortar or at least attempt
to I kind of missed and we will also
toss in a pinch of salt and what we want
to do is smash and grind that into a
paste okay we want something nice and
smooth so we will continue to mix and
mash smash and bash that garlic until it
looks something like this at which point
we'll stop and add the following
ingredients the first of which would be
some lemon zest and as we mentioned
we're doing a Meyer lemon aioli which is
why that zest is such a beautiful color
it kind of looks like an orange but it's
not and then we'll do a little pinch of
cayenne for various reasons as well as a
little bit of that freshly squeezed
Meyer lemon juice and yes feel free to
use regular lemons here but the Meyer
lemon is a little sweeter a little more
mild and a little more fragrant so if
you can find those Meyer lemons give a
try otherwise standard issue will be
fine and then we can go ahead and add
our homemade mayonnaise which this time
I bought at the store so we'll add that
animal stir everything together and once
all that's thoroughly and thoughtfully
mixed together that's pretty much it
what we are calling a Meyer lemon aioli
is done except of course for giving it a
little taste as is tradition
and once that's tasted exactly how we
want we can use it right away or simply
wrap it up and keep in the fridge until
needed and then besides a couple slices
of bread the only other major component
to this dish would be some kind of
shaved spring vegetable salad and I said
shaved but I really meant peeled so what
I have here is what they're calling
rainbow carrots which I have worked over
with my potato peeler to make those
beautiful thin strips I also have a
little bit of curly endive and not one
but two kinds of radishes I got some
watermelon radishes and some regular
peasant radishes and then last but not
least I'm also going to use some edible
flowers and the variety I'm using here
is called calendula which really don't
taste like much and if I'm being
perfectly honest so really just here for
the appearance but above and beyond that
they apparently have lots of health
benefits but anyway that's what I'll be
using the top my tartines
which at this point we are ready to
start building so first up we're going
to need to slice and toast a couple
pieces of nice French bread and I do
prefer day-old but fresh bread is fine
and what we'll do is toast that up
before covering it with copious amounts
of our Meyer lemon aioli so we want to
be very generous here spread it on
thickly all the way to the edges and
when in doubt add a little bit more and
if it looks like that one in the
foreground has a little extra really it
does that's mine and then once our toast
has been severely slathered with that
Mayo we will top it with our white
anchovy fillets which I like to do skin
side up because it's so beautiful and
I'm going to be placing down four fillet
per Tartine which I believe is the
perfect amount we want to get some of
that anchovy and every bite but we don't
want it to completely overpower our
shade vegetables on top so sure you
could cover the surface but for me this
is the perfect portion so we'll top that
with our anchovies and I'm going to show
you a huge pro tip here what we want to
do is slice these before we top them
with our vegetables and flowers and
that's because as I've learned the hard
way if you cut them once all your
veggies are piled on top everything kind
of flies all over and falls off and you
kind of wreck your presentation so for
me this is much much easier and once
those are cut we're ready to top with
our veggies so what we'll do is we'll
throw everything into a bowl except for
our flowers and we'll dress that very
simply with a little bit of freshly
squeezed lemon juice
a tiny drizzle of olive oil and we'll
toss that with our hands or any hand
like kitchen utensil and as soon as
that's mixed we can go ahead and top our
tartines and generally my strategy here
is to start with the lighter fluffier
stuff so I'll start by placing down that
curly endive and those beautifully
delicate strips of carrot and then once
that's placed down we will move on to
our slice radishes and we'll place those
in and around wherever we think they
look good and by the way I kind of feel
foolish telling you because it's pretty
obvious but there are so many kinds of
vegetables you can use for this I mean
things like artichoke or asparagus or
shaved fennel would be beautiful here so
part of the fun making something like
this is using exactly what you want you
are after all the Charlie Sheen of your
spring vegetable Tartine so it's up to
you to make sure you're winning speaking
of which once our shaved and our sliced
vegetables are down I'm going to go
ahead and pull off and scatter over my
flower petals and yes of course I did
this she loves me she loves me not game
and how did it turn out take a look she
loves me but anyway we're going to go
ahead and top our tartines with our
edible flowers and then last but not
least because I have an herb garden and
my Italian parsley plant had all this
new growth I decided to scatter over a
few tender leaves so I finished up with
a little bit of baby parsley and my
spring vegetable tartines were done and
looking just I was going to say gorgeous
but I always say gorgeous so I guess
I'll go with really gorgeous but anyway
besides they're studying appearance
these are by far especially if you use
the white anchovies one of the most
delicious cold sandwiches you'll ever
eat I mean come on we have crispy toast
soaked with a garlicky lemony mayonnaise
and then all that's top of those
insanely delicious white anchovies and
crisp crunchy shade vegetable salad just
absolutely amazing so I'm gonna go ahead
and take one more bite but before I do
let me go Bernie Sanders on this and
redistribute some of the topping there
we go so anyway that's it spring
vegetable Tartine I really hope this
inspires you to go out and find and try
white anchovies but I am realistic and I
do realize that some of you are not
going to try those no matter what I say
so at least promise me you'll try this
with tuna or bacon okay
I mean this is the kind of thing we
should be eatin in one form or another
like two or three times a week so I
really do hope you give this a try soon
head over to food wishes comm for all
the ingredient amounts and more info as
usual and as always enjoy
